item.description:
There are stars that have been determined to be causing problems with the balance of the universe. Pilots have been tasked with traveling to these stars and firing weapons at them in an attempt to destroy them and set the balance right.

Star Slayers is a dexterity game where players are tossing, throwing or sliding 3 Star Slayer ship cards at 5 stars with point values on them from 1 to 5. The ships only fire in certain directions. A line is traced from the weapons to the stars to determine if points are gained.

The first edition of Star Slayers is included on the back side of the cards from the first edition of Bocce Piatta.

Quarters is a dexterity game that is played in the same manner as the popular drinking game. Quarters includes 3 beer cup cards that players attempt to bounce their discs onto in order to give negative points to another player of their choice. When any player gets to 13 points the player with the least points wins the game.

The first edition of quarters is included on the back side of the cards in the first edition of Bocce Piatta.

Get Ready for Some Cosmic Fun Because Alien Run is Out of This World! Think you have a plan? Think again! Strategic thinking will be challenged around every bend.

What is Alien Run? Alien Run is a fast-paced strategic board game full of bizarre twist and turns. You can either play independent or with allies. During the race each player can be detoured by an opponent. The play of a Trump Card, Mystery Card, or landing on a Wormhole can send you into a galactic U-Turn. The secret to success is strategy. The player with the most orbs wins the game. It may sound easy, but it's not. Your strategic thinking will be challenged around every bend.

Each Player begins the game without Orbs, Trump Cards or Mystery Cards. That's right, empty handed. Players can collect Orbs from either game spaces, other players, Trump Cards, or Mystery Cards. Players have the opportunity to purchase Trump Cards from the bank to add to their arsenal, however there are purchasing rules. The Trump Cards are used for offensive and defensive plays during the game play. The secret to success is strategy, so keep your cards hidden and try to make some allies. Remember, it's not about who finishes first but who finishes with the most Orbs. The enticing bonus structure maybe just what a player needs to finish in the lead and be declared the winner. So get the popcorn ready, four players can finish in forty-five minutes. Game night will never be the same.

I almost forgot....

Don't get distracted by the hidden images in the game board. What a player misses can send them orbiting in the wrong direction. Stay focused and Alien Run victory can be had.

item.description:
Pókháló ("Spider-web") is a simple, enjoyable and funny family, children and party game.

The goal of the game is to escape from the spider's web with our chosen fly hero. The first one who escape succesfully wins the match. But it is not that easy to escape...

There is a double-sided board in the box. Each side is for different game variants and with different complexity. There is a simpler side (which is called "LegyezÅ‘" and recommended for players from 3-4 years) on which players can play a quick and easy game variant because all events (such as reroll, bonus steps etc.) are drawn on the board. The other side of the board (which is called "CselszövÅ‘" and recommended for players from 7-8 years) is for the more complex game variants. Game variants that are played on the "CselszövÅ‘" side need action cards (the box contains 40 action cards with some different effects). The game rules book contains 2 more game variants (for exemple one for the pro-gamers with challenging complexity) so the constant fun for everyone is guaranteed.

NO! is a quick and unpredictable turn-based casual card game for 3-7 players, designed by District Games.

At the beginning of the game, shuffle the 100 available cards and equally split them among the players. Everybody draws one card and a random player starts the game.

In your turn, flip the top card of your deck. Every card indicates how the turn passes from one player to the other, so the next player to play is simply the one indicated by the arrow you flipped.

If you have at least one card in your hand, right after somebody else's move you can shout NO! and play one card from your hand on top of the last card played by the active player. This way, that card will be the one to be followed now.

The first player who flips the last card of his deck wins the game.

Straight from minimalist Japan, FLIP MMCG is the ultimate resolution system. Flipping a coin... without the coin. Rock, paper, scissors... without the scissors. FLIP MMCG is a drawless system with immediate results. No table space required, plays completely in your hand. It also is a massive multiplayer card game, that only takes 1 minute. Awesome ice breaker at conventions, classrooms, parties, game nights, road trips, and picnics.

FLIP MMCG is a quick and simple competitive game for 2 or more players, by Charles Ward. The goal of the game is to gain as many FLIP cards as possible or be the last player in the game. Ignoring turn order, 2 players face off against each other. One player holds out a card, the other flips it over. The person on the blue side of the card wins, and takes a card from the loser.

The year is 1858 in Carson City, Nevada. You have rounded up a team of courageous cowboys, and your plan is to buy up the best parcels of land in this new town, then build them up with the most prosperous ranches, mines, saloons, etc.

Carson City: Big Box is a collection of the Carson City base game, the Gold & Guns expansion, and the upcoming Horses & Heroes expansion. The game board has been redesigned and updated to support a sixth player and the Horses & Heroes expansion. The game is played in four rounds, and in each one of them, the players choose one of the characters, which give certain advantages. When several players claim the same action, a duel is fought, and the player with the most firepower wins the action. In the end, the most prominent citizen in Carson City — as measured by victory points that can be won both during and after the game — wins.

Carson City: Gold & Guns, the first expansion, contains updated buildings and houses, new buildings, new double-sided characters, the "Indian" character (previously a promotional item at Spiel 2010), and a separate expansion called "The Outlaws".

Carson City: Horses & Heroes, the second expansion, lets players visit the rodeo to claim additional victory points and use horses to unlock special actions. Three new characters are also added to the game.

item.description:
Amidst the frozen ruins of an ancient city, wizards battle in the hopes of discovering the treasures of a fallen empire. In the fantasy skirmish wargame Frostgrave, each player takes on the role of a wizard from one of ten schools of magic, and builds his band of followers. The wizard's apprentice usually accompanies his master, and more than a dozen other henchman types are available for hire, from lowly thugs to heavily armored knights and stealthy thieves. Wizards can expand their magical knowledge by unlocking ancient secrets and may learn up to 80 different spells.

While individual games of Frostgrave are quick and can easily be played in an hour or two, it is by connecting them into an ongoing campaign that players will find the most enjoyment. The scenarios given in the book are merely the beginning of the limitless adventures that can be found amidst the ruins of the Frozen City.

Osprey Games and North Star miniatures will produce a full range of official Frostgrave miniatures. This includes wizards and apprentices from all ten schools of magic, and all the soldiers that can be hired for their warbands. The wizards, apprentices and specialist henchmen such as the apothecary and thief are metal sculpts while a multi-part plastic box set offers huge variety in building the more common soldier types.

item.description:
Don't Be That Guy is a casual party-style card game which highlights the annoying natures of other people. Each card presents a situation that is found by most people to be irritating (Examples: Driving slowly in the left lane, Teaching someone's child to swear, etc).

Game play is as follows: (Normal Rules)
One player reads the card and shows it to the other players. 
Each player votes to see which player is most likely to be guilty of this bad habit. The person with the most votes is "That Guy" and receives the card. The first person who hits 7 cards loses, as the game is called "DON'T be that guy".

Alternate Rules:
For groups where people are not as familiar with each other, before the first card is read, each player chooses a famous person (real or fictional, male or female, etc) and plays as that person for the rest of the game.

item.description:
RIOT is a Board Game about social conflict, the sides involved are Police and Rioters. A simulation of urban political tension and uprising.

In RIOT the player has to choose a side and rule the streets of the city maintainig control of different areas in a situation that is out of any control.

The game is to factions, factions with different powers. Specifically are Autonomous, Anarchists, Nationalists and Police.
The game is turn-based, and end when a faction reaches its goal. The 4 factions have different goals.

In summary, they struggle for control of the district of the city, while the Police tried to block the protesters.

On his turn factions of troublemakers can do a number of actions based on the buildings they control. Police instead follows different rules.

Each faction has specific markers with different powers.

The clashes between the various forces occur on the streets of the city with the aim of occupying buildings.

The clashes and movements are simple. The game has a good setting, with easy mechanical.

RIOT is a game of control territory with worker placement and card driving.

item.description: Mittlere is an interesting Jass point-trick taking game for three players. What makes this Jass stand out is that players attempt to avoid having the middle score.

The players move their pawns around the board. Movement is determined by a die. Each player controls two character cards (one male and one female) with different relation factors and special abilities. If the relation factors of the two cards complement each other, the player gets money, when he gets on a space "Beziehung". If not, he loses money.

On some spaces the players can buy or sell oil wells or draw event-cards. If a player gets on a space "Zentrum der Macht" he gets the corresponding card, which grants special advantages. The player keeps the card till he loses it or another player takes it. If a player gets on a character-space for a character he doesn't own, he has to swap the character for his own card of the same gender with the owner of that character.

The first player to own $ 3000000 wins the game.
12 promotional cards for the Polish version with themes to attract the board gamers: board games, video games, role playing, comics, horror, sci-fi etc.

item.description:
Relative Paradox could best be described as a Deck Building Game, with mechanics including Strategy, Hand Management, and a little bit of Luck. The point is to match up History A with People B and multiplier/bonus for History C with Cosmos and Paradox Cards create "trouble" that alter history all together. All the cards are easily recognizable to their time in history, so you don't need to be a Historian to play. This game features all Public Domain Time Travelers including Professor Helvetius and Doctor Omega.

2 to 8 Players will have to take their Traveler into Time and Space to collect pieces of history and put them back together. First players will be dealt one time traveler to represent them during the game, these are Traveler Cards, The Traveler you are dealt is who you will represent throughout the game. Then each player is Dealt Five Cards from the main deck, the remainder are separated into one pile per the amount of players (i.e. 2 somewhat even piles for two players) and a card is placed face up on all sides (see the image above), these cards are now obtainable.

Each turn you can either create a timeline (matching cards with same symbols) or draw a card from the tabletop that is obtainable. A player can have as many or as few cards as needed in their hand at one time. When you make a pair, you do not draw to replenish. Also, if you have a timeline available to lay--you must use it and lay your pair/three of a kind. Each Timeline Card will have a value that will count towards your final tally, these are called Timeline Points. Each Traveler interacts with a particular timeline differently, either giving them a bonus/multiplier for Timeline Points or immunity from a certain Paradox.

In Galaxy Command, 1 to 4 players take the role of a galaxy commander. Each tries to maintain a delicate balance of resources, military power, and technological achievements as they explore the galaxy. Game play is fast and fun with varied decisions to be made by each player during their missions.

In each game of Galaxy Command there are near and far systems that must be overcome in order to bring in new resources and wealth. Near systems must be explored before attempting to reach far systems. Some far systems require key technology to be reached with any chance of success. Near systems provide resources that can build your military strength and develop technologies allowing you to overcome challenges as you go deeper into space.

During a turn players reveal a system card (starting with near systems) on their mission path and try to overcome its obstacles. Next they collect wealth and resources and build military strength and technology. And finally a random event card is drawn that may affect one or all players in the game. The event cards are also the timer on the game. When the event cards run out the game is over. The Galaxy Command (all players) saves or fails in its mission by reaching enough far systems to sustain its empire. Each Galaxy Commander (individual player), provided the empire is saved, can be the best among peers by his contribution (score) to the overall mission success.

No two games will play the same as the systems you get, and the decisions you make will change game to game.The event cards affect different players during each game.The game plays in 15 to 45 minutes depending on the number of players and how quick they play.The game is playable for ages 8 to 800 (if you're from planet Cirius...).

Originally published by Robert as a print and play solitaire game with 19 cards. In this version we have taken the original game, added a multi-player element by expanding the deck to 54 cards, new artwork, planets, and challenges but keeping the clean mechanics in place. The game was well received as it was and now we have made it playable from 1 to 4 players yet still keeping it playable in under 45 minutes.

A late game in SS series.

Covering the Meiji Ishin in whole Japan.

The map covers from Satsuma to Ezo by areas.
The game is composed of recruitment, move, combat, control then redeployment.
The game starts just after the battle of Toba-Fushimi. The last Shogun Yoshinobu was still in Osaka.
Sattyo starts the game in Western part of Japan. But, they have more talented leaders than Edo-bakufu.

Victory is decided by victory points, collecte during each redeployment phases by controlling important areas such as Kyoto, Osaka, Edo, Nagasaki.

Trivia game with questions related to the German city of Karlsruhe. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. 
Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

name.value: Monopoly: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles Collector's Edition

item.description:
Monopoly: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles Collector's Edition follows our favorite "Heroes in a Half Shell" as they battle their way through 22 of the most notorious villains in the turtle world. Six custom-sculpted colored vinyl tokens include Leonardo, Donatello, Michelangelo, Raphael, Splinter & Casey Jones, Use your Turtle Power and come kick some enemy butt with Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles Monopoly.

Includes:


 Six custom-sculpted colored vinyl tokens include Leonardo, Donatello, Michelangelo, Raphael, Splinter & Casey Jones.



 Custom sculpted Pizza Slices & Pizza Boxes replace traditional Houses & Hotels.



 Custom designed game board revisits the original TV show's notorious villains.



 Chance & Community Chest cards are transformed into Mutagen and Allies cards.

These are 25mm scale skirmish level rules sold by Lamming Miniatures which include both campaign rules and man to man battle rules encompassing sieges and naval combat. The campaign rules are interesting in that each army begins by sailing their forces to an unexplored island where they explore and expand, manage finances, handle supplies and exports, deal with treachery and eventually the conquest of the other player's territories.

Soccer Manager Express is a Print-and-Play game available for free on BGG! Players assume the role of the Manager of one of six teams vying for the League Title at the end of the season.

Each player starts by drafting a team of Academy players with basic skills and a modest budget of cash. They can then buy Premier players from the Transfer Market and build a small squad to challenge for title glory.

The league matches consist of super-quick rounds of dice rolling, where custom dice for various players and positions determine the outcome. The team that performs the best over the course of the season will accumulate the most points and be crowned the League Champions!

item.description:
Players boast about the elusive creatures they claim to have seen in the mountains. But can you always believe their stories?

Every player gets five cards, showing one of five animals with quantities of 1, 2 or 3. The starting player plays a card face down on the table, making a claim such as "I have seen one Yak", then draws a new card. Next player adds to that stack, raising the claim, either by raising the number or the size of the animal. The cards in the stack represent the animals which have actually been around. Play continues in clockwise order until a player calls a bluff and flips open the stack. If it doesn't contain at least as many animals of the last kind as were announced, the bluffing player takes the stack as a penalty, if it does, the caller takes them.
Beware, there are some special cards that players can sneak into the stack, those which reduce the numbers on the cards or those that make all animals appear as the same kind.
When the draw pile is exhausted, the player with least penalty cards wins.

The game is a simplified reimplementation of Bluff im Zoo.

item.description: A classic light 25mm miniatures wargame at roughly 1"=25' (10 paces) and a figure ratio of 1:20. Including battles covering Egypt/Assyria, Greek/Persia, Macedonians/The Successors, Rome/Carthage and Rome/Barbarians with rules and scenarios.

A Pachisi-like game, with a theme based on the French-German conflict in WWI.

Major differences:
Two pawns on the same space block others. Pawns on circular spaces are safe. The winner is the first player to move all pawns "home".

Likely published during WWI.

............Planet Trading Company......................, es un juego de 2 a 4 jugadores. El objetivo del juego es extraer recursos de las minas del planeta Xerath y enviarlo a la Federación espacial.

Comerciar es el Futuro!!

Componentes
 4 Tableros de Base Minera
1. Zona No Enviado
2. Zona de Enviado 
3. Zona Acciones

4 Contadores de acción

36 Cartas de Minerales, 5 tipos diferentes: 12 cartas de 1punto de recursos, 10 cartas de 2 puntos de recursos, 6 cartas de 4 puntos de recursos, 6 cartas de 4 puntos de recursos piratas, 2 cartas de 6 puntos de recursos piratas.
1. Cantidad de recursos
2. Piratas y cantidad de dados

33 Cartas de Transporte, 3 tipos diferentes: 24 cartas de Recolectores, 6 cartas de Guardianes, 2 cartas de Comandantes. 
1. Nombre de Carta
2. Cantidad de dados

2 dados numéricos

Preparación

1. Ubica las 36 cartas de Minerales bocabajo repartidas en 5 grupos. 
2. Baraja las 33 cartas de Transporte y dejalas a un costado de la mesa.
3. Cada jugador toma dos cartas de Recolectores, un Tablero de la Base Minera y un contador de acción. 
4. Determina el primer jugador al azar y cuando este termine su turno continua el jugador que esta sentado a su derecha.



............Planet Trading Company............. is a game in for 2-4 players. Which you have to act as a manager of actions to achieve the objective is to extract as many resources.components
 
4 baseboards Mining
1. Zone Not Submitted
2. Zone Submitted
3. Zone Actions

4 Counters action

36 Letters of Minerals, 5 different types: 12 cards of 1 point of resources, 10 cards 2 resource points, 6 letters of 4 resource points, 6 letters of 4 points pirates resources, 2 letters of 6 points pirates resources.
1. Amount of resources
2. Pirates and number of dice

33 Letters of Transportation, 3 different types: 24 letters from collectors, 6 cards Guardian, 2 letters of Commanders.
1. Name Charter
2. Amount of dice

2 dice number

preparation

1. Locate the 36 cards dealt face down Minerals in 5 groups.
2. Shuffle the 33 letters of Transportation and leave to one side of the table.
3. Each player takes two cards from collectors a Mining Base Board and a counter action.
4. Determine the first player at random and when it has completed its continuous turn the player who sits to his right.

name.value: More Wargaming Pioneers: Early Wargames Volume 4

item.description: Ancient and Medieval, World War II, and Modern battle and skirmish rules by Tony Bath, Lionel Tarr and Michael Korns respectively, edited by John Curry as part of the ongoing History of Wargaming Project.

A fresh take on how word games can be quick, semi-cooperative, and fun!
Build a great word search for your temporary partner to find lots of words. 2 letter dice are rolled; all players write those same 2 letters anywhere on their own grid. Repeat until grids are filled, then pass the grid to a neighbor who has a limited time to write down all the words they can find. Both Builder and Finder score together for the same grid!

Tavern Fame is the game of strong ale and tall tales.

Players compete with their fellow heroes to drink, bluff and slay your way into the hearts and minds of the patrons around you.

Tavern Fame is a press-your-luck bidding game for 2-5 players where each player is assigned a high-fantasy character that is boasting about how many enemies they recently killed on their adventures.

The first player to get to 10 patrons, or the player with the most patrons when the patron pool runs out, wins the game.

Each player starts with 3 patrons, 2 drinks and a character card.

Each turn, the active players buys a round of drinks from the drink pool for the other players and then flips the top Enemy card, which lists what the enemy is, the enemy's health, and the rewards a player gets on a successful slay. They start the round's bid, stating how many enemies they killed. The round continues with each player either believing the bidder, or bidding a higher number. At any time, though, any player can call out the bidder.

If no one wants to up the bid further, the bidder now has to slay the enemies by building a dice pool out of their character's strength, any bonuses they have against the drawn enemy, and spent drinks, where one drink equals one extra dice. Every dice result that is equal to, or greater than the enemy's health, is one successful kill. If the bidder less enemies than they bidded, the caller gets one of their patrons. If the bidder kills more enemies than they bidded, they succeed and not only get one of the patrons from the caller, but they also get the drinks and patrons listed on the enemy card. If they kill exactly the same amount that they bidded, they activate the perfect bluff bonus on their character card, as well as the enemy's reward and the caller's patron.

The winner of the last round (either the bidder or the caller) is the active player for the next.

item.description:
Japanese style board game: Master the art of trade on the streets of ancient Japan.

IKI is a medium weight strategy game for 2-4 players, ages 13+, with a playing time of 60-90 minutes. It bases itself in the city of Edo, or what we now know today as Tokyo, Japan.

Edo was a thriving city with an estimated population of one million, half townspeople and half samurai. With a huge shopping culture, Edo’s main district, Nihonbashi, was lined with shops, selling kimonos, rice, and so much more.

Nihonbashi will be the focus of this game. IKI: A Game of EDO Artisans will bring you on a journey through the famed street of old Tokyo. Hear the voices of Nihonbashi Bridge’s great fish market. Meet the professionals, classing from 700­-800 different jobs. Enter the interactivity of the shoppers and vendors. Become one with the townspeople.

One of the main professions in the world of Edo is the artisan. Each of the Edo artisans use their own skill of trade to support the townspeople’s lives. In this game, not only are there artisans, but street vendors, sellers at the shops, and professions unique to this time and age. Meet the puppet masters, putting on a show. Meet the ear cleaners that people would line up for. This game just got a whole lot more exciting.

The goal of this game is to become the annual Edoite, best personifying what is known as “IKI." What is “IKI,” you ask? “IKI” is an ancient philosophy, believed to be the ideal way of living among people in Edo. Knowing the subtleties of human nature, being refined and attractive... These are all elements of a true IKI master.

item.description:
All scientists agree, the human civilization is now facing the greatest catastrophe of its history. We are in the dawn of year 5341, we thought our scientific progresses and collective intelligence would preserve us, but a major disaster is looming: the universe began to regress, threatening our civilization of a total annihilation.

As an elite member of the Human Organization to Preserve Existence (HOPE), your mission is to prevent this plight from happening. You'll have to navigate your ship to distant galaxies in order to restore life in the universe. Be swift and bold, the future of all humanity is at stake...

But remain cautious in your task because a traitor may lie among you, thwarting your heroic plans.

item.description:
Travel back through history to a settlement called Samara, where you lead a group of builders. At the start of the game, they can build only a sandcastle, cave or huts. For more complex buildings, you first invest time in skills, strength, or new workers. Building special projects gives you benefits or hurts all your rivals. In the end you want to have the most prestigious buildings.

The worker timetrack is the key mechanism. Each of your choices costs a number of your workers a number of months. Your workers can spend time on:


 Improving skills to build with wood (saw tool), stone (trowel tool) and glass (blowing tool).
 Building houses or special projects.
 Getting a new worker or exercising to become a stronger worker.
 Going on vacation.


The spaces on the game board determine how many workers (1-4 on the left board axis) are occupied how many months (1-9 on the bottom board axis). Players plan to let their workers spend time effectively, choosing when to invest and when to build for prestige. The prestige points determine who is the best foreman of Samara.

name.value: Die Menagerie: Ein sehr unterhaltendes Kinderspiel

item.description:
Objective: get most money/chips

At the beginning of the game, the track is filled with a chip on each of the 25 illustrated animal spaces. Then, players take turns moving their pawns by rolling three dice and advancing to the indicated space. If you land on a chip you may keep it if you call the number and can identify the illustrated animal. If you fail you must place an additional chip. Throwing '3x3' just clean the map.

Description from the publisher:

WWE Superstar Showdown features six of WWE's greatest superstars — Daniel Bryan, Roman Reigns, John Cena, Big Show, Randy Orton, and Big E — in a game of miniature combat driven by specialized card decks that highlight the unique style and signature moves for each WWE superstar.

A single match in WWE Superstar Showdown can be played in as little as ten minutes. The game expands with rules linking a series of matches to form an event, creating a longer and more in-depth play experience. With four different match cards, players can play a variety of different matches, further augmented with stipulation cards that introduce special rules to the contest. Players in an event can improve their superstar between matches by earning and adding powerful bonus cards to their superstar decks.

Can you dominate the ring? Will your team go down in history as the greatest phenomenon the world has ever known?

item.description:
Ð§ÑƒÐ´ÐµÑÐ½Ñ‹Ðµ Ð±Ð°ÑˆÐ½Ð¸ ("Wonderful Towers") is a card game in which players will turn their towers from upside down to normal position.

In the beginnign of the game each player is dealt 7 cards that form his upside-down tower. Each round the player must perform one of the following actions: take a card from the deck and replace a card in his tower with it; or you play the property of one of previously discarded cards. The winner will be the first one to build his wonderful tower.

For a long time there is a war, and opponents have decided to resolve it not through a big battle but a struggle between their best knights. But chivalry is able to integrate even the most irreconcilable enemies. Many soldiers from both sides united with different relations: friendship, lifesaving, vows of chivalry, and even love.
 
In Ð¡ÐµÑ€Ð´Ñ†Ð° Ð¸ Ð”Ð¾ÑÐ¿ÐµÑ…Ð¸ ("Hearts and Armour") players are divided into two teams. The task of each team - to defeat the opposing team, and killing or wounding more fighters from the opposite side. However, each player draws a relation card of one of the opponents. He can not win if the opponent is killed.

Waterloo 2015 is an abstract game about the battle of Waterloo in june 1815.
There are NO DICE and NO combat CARDS in this game.
You will only find Event cards, in order to ensure replayability.
You have to carefully plan your moves and assaults, like in the Chess...

This game uses hexagonal zones, and some zones are crucial : Hougoumont, Mont St.Jean, La Haye Sainte, etc...
In order to win, you have to control a certain number of crucial zones.

One player controls the Allied army (Anglo-Prussian), and the other controls the French army. Each army includes 3 types of units : infantry (normal and elite), cavalry (normal and elite), and artillery. You charge and pursue with the cavalry, you bombard and defend with the artillery, BUT you control the terrain with the infantry... 
Each zone contains up to 8 units.

Turn sequence :
Allied Approach.
French Approach.
French Engagement.
Allied Engagement.
Reorganisation.
Victory conditions.

This simple roll-and-move game was published as a insert in the magazine "Fernsehwoche" in the 1970s. The players begin at "Start" and try to be the first to reach the Grand Hotel on Vacation Island. On some spaces evets occur, that hinder or benefit the players. If a player gets on a space that is already occupied by onother player, the other player has to back up 7 spaces.

The original Champions of Aerim have long since faded from memory. Technology has begun its slow and steady rise within civilization, while many still cling desperately to the magic of old. Astaria itself has grown into a vast, sprawling empire, yet rebellion is carried on whispers from deep within the shadows. The strength of steam could spark a revolution. But for the Eternals, the cycle continues as it always has. For them, there is only... strife.

Strife: Shadows and Steam is a stand-alone sequel to Strife: Legacy of the Eternals. Using the same core mechanics, Strife: SaS introduces new characters, abilities and a unique twist or two that will be sure to add a fresh take on this exciting game. This sequel is also fully compatible with the original game, so you can face off with champions of Aerim from different ages!

Strife, a two-player strategy card game that plays in around an hour, is a game where you always know your opponent's options. Aside from mastering the unique combo-creating gameplay of your champions, figuring out how to outmaneuver your opponent is where the true challenge lies.

Each player has the same hand of ten champions and will simultaneously play them as they fight over key locations throughout Aerim worth varying victory points. Each champion has a battle ability that's triggered during battles and a legacy ability that can be used only while on top of the legacy pile. This creates an intricate latticework of strategy for the players as each champion must be considered for not only what he can do in the current battle, but for which ability he will add to the next.

Further impacting the critical decisions within the game is the Fatestone tie-breaking system. The Fatestone starts at a value of one, and whoever holds the Fatestone die loses all ties; that player may instead pass the stone to his opponent to claim a victory in that tie, but doing so raises the value of the Fatestone by one each time it is passed. At the end of the game, the player holding the Fatestone adds its final value to his victory point tally. Whichever player has the most victory points at the end of the game wins!

item.description:
SEAL Team Flix is a fully co-operative or solo tactical dexterity game that pits 1-4 players against the forces of terrorism. Taking inspiration from several military-themed first-person shooter video games, SEAL Team Flix incorporates flicking, dice rolling, and character standees into an exciting, unique combination that will have the whole table standing up.

The game has two modes: campaign and skirmish. In campaign mode, players embark on an eight-mission non-linear adventure. Individual SEALs will get promoted several times over the course of the campaign...if they live. In skirmish mode, simply play one of the 17 missions as a standalone set-piece.

SEAL Team Flix is an objective-based game, with primary and secondary objectives which need to be resolved to successfully complete each mission. For example, in some missions, you must locate and acquire intelligence against the terrorist organization Gaia's Hope. In others, you must disarm time bombs or rescue hostages. While you are given intelligence at the beginning of each mission as to the number and nature of the objectives that need to be completed, every game will be different because you will never know where on the map they are until you physically locate them with your SEALs. The game's difficulty scales both with the number of SEALs playing as well as with three optional difficulty levels.

IMPORTANT ERRATA: Somehow the Sentry positions were left off the printed boards included in the game. You can see images of the correct Sentry Position placement on pages 6 and 10 in the rulebook, but you can also download the Sentry Errata PDFin the files section, which contains enlarged images of the maps and their sentry positions.

item.description:
A new game by Masao Suganuma, of Machi Koro's fame, based on the eponymous manga by Kazuhiko Shimamoto, which is basically a parody of the "Super Sentai" series, better known in America for its "Power Rangers" version.

In this game, players are would-be heroes working for the Hero Company, which such fancy names as "Choco-Red", "Soft-Yellow" or "Macaron-Navy". Each turn, which represent a week of game time, they try to resolve three different cases of increasing difficulty (ending with a final battle of supposedly epic proportions), in order to get the best grades from the company. Each hero can only try to resolve one of those, though heroes can queue to resolve the same case. Some cases only rewards the player who actually resolved it (ie, beat the threshold to resolve it with the die/dice), and others rewards every player who participate.

To spice up things, each hero has a hand of skill cards to either boost his capacities or mess up his partners' plan.

While it is important to cooperate to overcome the different cases, in the end, there can be only one winner, so this isn't a cooperative game.

name.value: Hey Bartender!: The Cocktail Themed Party Game

item.description:
Hey Bartender! is a cocktail-themed party game for 2-4 players. Players move around the game board collecting ingredients, and develop their world-famous cocktails, with the goal of gathering and matching various ingredients to shake their cocktails. Get ready now for the challenge from your family, friends, and lovers.

How to Play Instruction

1) PREPARATION: Place the game board in the center of the playing area Each player receive 1 chip board, and choose one character to represent him/her while traveling around the board .

2) BARTENDER: Select as Bartender a player who will also maintain the supplies and inventory for the bar. A Bartender who plays in the game must keep his/her chip board separate from the bar board.

3) BARBOARD: The bar boards holds all ingredient chips, cocktail cards, shakers, and cocktail chips. The board supplies ingredient chips to players and exchange cock-tail chips to player upon completing every single cocktail. If the Bar runs of out ingredients, the Bartender is allowed to issue ingredients needed by writing on any ordinary paper.

4) THE PLAY: Starting with the Bartender, each player in turn throws the dice. The player with the highest total starts the play: Place your character on the corner marked “OPEN/START”, throw the dice and move your characters in the direction of the arrow the number of spaces indicated by the dice. After you have completed your play, the character turn passes to the left. Two or more characters may rest on the same space at the same time. According to the space your character reaches, you are entitled to obtain the ingredient designated in the space or follow instruction stated in the space such as Chance, Give, Take, or obliged to rest a turn, jump to any space, or to exchange cocktail card, etc.

5) WHO WIN? The first player to complete all their cocktail cards in hand. If time limit of a game play is set, player with the highest combined total scores of ingredient in hand (please refer to score table) will be the winner. Any completed cocktail chip is awarded 10 bonus points.

Play Option 1: The first player to complete all their cocktail cards in hand wins.
Play Option 2: If time limit of a game play is set (average of 25 minutes), player with the highest combined total scores of ingredient in hand wins.

Players must dodge and utilize Bartender's instructions as it may force you to give or take ingredient chips from other players to make this game unpredictable.

Introduction
Old legends say that a long time ago gods lived in the great boreal forest of Canada. If one got lost in the woods, one might have seen among the trees one of their totems, which were sacred objects they used to channel their energy. The legends also say that the gods loved to play and that, every few years, they would transform the entire forest into their playground and compete for control of these totems.

Borealis is an epic game of conquest in which players represent old gods of the boreal forest, trying to capture each other's totems using units with various abilities. It is played on a modular hex-based board, which is created anew at the start of each game by the players and can be transformed during it. It lasts 9 rounds, and to each round is assigned a season, summer or winter, which affects the units' movements and the arrival of reinforcements.

Goal
Be the player with the most Victory Points at the end of the 9th round. At the end of each round, a Victory Point is awarded to the player who controls the most totems. If there's a tie, no Victory Point is awarded. If, at any point, a player's victory becomes inevitable because his or her point lead is greater than the number of rounds remaining, the game should end then.

Getting to know Thailands provinces, its sights, traditions, as well as local specialities.

Game-play: Fun and strategy game in rounds from 2 to 9 players.

Goal of the game is to to be the first to have no cards left in hand, or if not possible to have the lowest amount of scoring points on hand.

name.value: アイスクール 日本語版

item.description:
The lunch break is almost there and all of the young penguins would finally get the fish they’ve been craving. However, some rascals think they are quick enough to snatch some of the fish before the lunch break starts, but they have forgotten one thing – the Hall Monitor! Each school day one of the penguins is designated to watch over the school, and this is his moment to shine – for each rascal penguin he catches he would get additional fish!

A fun run takes place – the rascals are running everywhere and trying to snatch some fish on their way, but the Hall Monitor is trying to catch each and one of them to have some order in the school. Who will be more successful?

ICECOOL is a flicking game in which each round one of the players takes the role of the Hall Monitor (also called "the Catcher") – his aim will be to catch each other penguin and get points for that. The others (also known as "Runners") will try to run through several doors, thus gaining fish (that give them points) on their way. When either the Hall Monitor has caught each other penguin once or any of the others has gone through all 3 doors that have fish on them, the round is over. Each player will take the role of the Hall Monitor once and at the end of the game the winner will be the one with the most points on their fish cards.

The penguins can be flicked in a straight line, make curves and even jump over the walls! Each player will have to use the best of their skills in order to get the most points in this fun and exciting game. It's not just cool, it's ICECOOL!

item.description:
User summary

The game consists of 10 thick wooden tiles with the front and back of each tile having one of five patterns (suits). Each tile has different patterns on the front and back, and no two tiles are alike. Thus, each pattern appears four times. So, for example, each of the four tiles showing the rose pattern has a different one of the remaining four patterns on the reverse side.

The tiles are randomly placed on the table on their sides on so that each player sees exactly one of the two patterned faces of each tile (the players sit across from each other). The first player rotates one tile 90 degrees so that it is standing up. Next, the other player topples it either towards or away from herself (she chooses) so that one of the two patterned sides is now face up. She then puts the tile into a pile on the side of the table so that the revealed patterned side remains face up. After completing these steps, the players reverse roles.

The goal of the game is to build a complete 2-D tile pyramid, with four tiles in the bottom layer, three tiles in the second layer, two tiles in the third layer and one tile on top. When building on the second or higher layers, a tile can only be placed if it matches the face up pattern of one of the tiles it is being placed on. The pyramid can be built in any order (e.g., work on the second layer can begin before the bottom layer is completed).

Players may not communicate verbally or otherwise.

Forming arts with strings, Flashing your inspiration!

This game is a puzzle game with some strings. You use strings to form the pictures depicted by the cards. You need to be careful to match the lower and upper part of the strings where they cross each other.

It is the point of the game that there are three types of strings in this game. Red is one set consists of 2 circular strings, blue is a long string, and yellow is ne set consists of 2 circular strings crossing each other. You have to form the picture with a correct string(for example, the picture have only one string, you have to use a blue string). So, you need to be able to separate them from each other.

There are three rules, Normal Rule, Race Rule, and Kid's Rule. Race rule is for players who want a handicap. Kid's Rule is for playing with children.

MOVIE:https://youtu.be/Mf-GVJItLcc

User summary

A board game based on a bunch of anime that are not to be named (too obviously).

The players are flying delivery services and should pick up and deliver as many goods as possible on the board. On his turn, a player will roll dice and play any number of action cards that will benefit him, then move his pawn on the board, picking up and delivering objects.

name.value: Lapitta, the island in the sky

item.description:
User summary

A board game based on an anime that is not to be named too obviously.

The players run back and forth on a crumbling bridge, between the flying ship and the island in the sky. Each turn, the player rolls dice and decides which to use for movement and which to use for destroying the bridge. The removed bridge tiles can become items and whatever the players find on the island will decide what points they will get for what items. The players can also bump into each other and steal items.

User summary

A simple yet engaging card game featuring all possible tanks from WW2. The players start with a lineup of hidden tanks and can place them in the front line or the back line. Cards can be flipped to be revealed, and revealed tanks can attack other player's tanks.

While each attack is extremely simple (roll a D6 below target number), the variations and special effects of cards allows for a tactical game.
Tanks are all real tanks and listed by name and categories, but the setting of the game is in an imaginary future where people fight out battles with various tank miniatures, hence the team of tanks can be any combination of any nationality, and the theme is light-hearted.

MOVIE : https://youtu.be/SC8S-VFiUqg

The sands of time sweep across the ages, burying the cities and monuments of civilizations, leaving only whispers of the glory of ancient societies.

The Sands of Time is a civilization-building game set loosely in classical antiquity, on a board inspired by a Roman-era map. Each player rules over a civilization in the ancient world, attempting exploits that will be remembered long after the civilization has withered. Each turn, players will select two action cards, which represent edicts delivered by the player to his populace, announcing what aspects of the empire he/she wishes to address: building structures, implementing advances, migrating population, initiating combat, annexing new territories, instituting reforms to manage the empire’s unrest, building trade routes, demanding tribute, and -- crucially –- recording Chronicles about his/her reign.

The central element of the game's scoring system, Chronicle cards represent claims of great accomplishments. To score a chronicle, the player must have a "heritage" level commensurate with the claim he/she is making: claims of great works will only be believed and perpetuated if the player's civilization has established a reputation in the relevant civilization category (cultural, civil, or political).

Actions generally require the payment of resources (crops or gold), and action costs correlate either to the player's empire size or the player's Unrest level. Unrest increases when a player's territories become too crowded, or when a player re-uses an action card, or when a player voluntarily presses on his populace to squeeze additional productivity out of them. Managing Unrest is a central concern for the player throughout the game.

Players must strike the right balance between competition and peaceful interaction with their neighbors, to propel their civilizations from insignificant, forgettable kingdoms into empires worthy of the attention of historians!

item.description:
User summary

A standalone expansion to Tank Hunter 2e.

Tank Hunter is set in a fictional future where players pit their army of model tanks against each other. Each player has a small unit of various tanks from WW2, and deploy them against each other trying to defeat the other player's tanks, infantries and guns.

Jäger contains more tanks, more infantry and more guns, and can both be played as a standalone game or integrated with the base set.

Terrible Monster is a battle card game for two players. Each player starts with four lives, two counter tokens, and a hand of five cards from the deck of 16 cards, with players taking turns to draw a card and play up to two cards against each other, possibly countering or re-countering them.

The first player to defeat the other player wins.

item.description:
Shuffle Heroes is card game for two players set in a fantasy steampunk world filled with Lovecraftian monstrosities.

Each game, you draft two heroes and shuffle their cards together, forming your draw deck. This provides a lot of possibilities for different deck combinations while keeping the deck construction fast and easy.

The game-play is pretty straight-forward. During your turn, you either play a card, activate your hero or replenish your hand. However, when played right, you can chain effects together with devastating outcomes.

Your ultimate goal is to defeat enemy heroes either by reducing their health to zero or wearing them down by destroying cards from their deck.

One of the main mechanics in Shuffle Heroes is the so-called deck deconstruction. During the game, you can decide which cards you destroy from your opponent's deck. This decision heavily influences what your opponent can draw in the next turns.

item.description:
User summary

A card battle where the players compete for laid out treasures. Players take turns putting out one of their summoned characters face down on any treasure they want. When all have placed, the cards are turned face up and activated, and the player that has the highest total on each treasure gets that treasure.

Each card also have special effects, and character cards are also turned face up each time someone places a new character card on the same treasure. This allows for strange combos and traps.

User summary

A card game in which the players try to pit together couples of the same sex in order to get points.

Nine characters (girls or boys, but not both) are lined up, each getting a certain personality from a deck of personality cards. Each player gets one date spot card. On a player's turn, they can either exchange their date spot with one of the open ones, or put another personality on a character, or show their hand card (date spot) and pick two characters who will date on that spot. If the requirements on the date spot card match the personalities of the characters, the player will earn points. A perfect match means a couple is formed, and the characters are removed from the game.

The game ends when there is just 1 (poor) character left, or if the personalities deck runs out of cards.

User summary

A board game where the players' goal is to invite as many cats as possible into their house. Fire cats are walking around the board, and the players roll dice and use cards to get the cats to come to their house.

The player who gets most cats into his house wins.

War of Wonders is a skirmish miniature game set in an alternate, grim World War II fought by superhuman beings.

Details:
War of Wonders Miniature Game is a fast paced 30mm strategic skirmish game based on the deeply immersive setting of Project H.O.P.E. RPG by authors Simone Fini and Riccardo Giuliani, published by Limana Press.
In War of Wonders extraordinary human beings with powers beyond imagination fight on WW II battlefields alongside regular troops and iconic heavy tanks to change History. National heroes, monsters born in laboratories and mysterious beings with their own secret goals: every and each of them will add new tactics, game options and strategies to your games.

Setting:
Nazi Germany declares war on Europe, and its army is unstoppable. Prodigious beings appear on the battlefields to support the Wehrmacht's efforts: flying men shower flames upon the enemy; women wearing iron masks punch through tank armour; bloodthirsty beasts devour entire regiments. The world is about to succumb to the might of the Third Reich. Aaron Spiegelmann, a Jewish scientist who escaped from the Mauthausen concentration camp, is the only hope for the Allied Forces to stop the Nazis. Spiegelmann is the genius who created the Wunderkammer, a new technology that allowed the Germans to create real superheroes with extraordinary powers. With his guidance, the US Army launches Project H.O.P.E. in order to produce their own genetically modified humans to be deployed on the battlefields. As the war rages on and every army creates its own Meta-Humans and war machines, Natural Prodigies, unscrupulous Adventurers and even secretive groups of Warlocks step into battle. From the European battlefields to the Pacific Islands, a conflict like never before is unleashed and spreads with no boundaries: humanity will forever remember it as the first War of Wonders.

Gear Grinders is a board game where players control one of four unique characters maneuvering around an arena to attack the other players. Each character has their own attacks, stats (attack, defense, movement), life, gear slots, gear cost, and steam tank size. Steam is used to power different attacks or shift gears from first to second gear.

The arena has three different steam vents located throughout. A normal steam vent, a gear vent, and a hatch vent. These can be turned on or off with a die roll. When the vents are on, moving over them can increase the amount of steam in your tank but at the cost of some life. Gear cards could appear on the gear vent with a die roll. The hatch vents are used to move a player from the gear vent.

Gear cards are equipped by players to modify the player's stats. Playing cards are used to help launch attacks or defend. Combat is determined by a die roll adding any modifiers and comparing it to the defender's defense with their modifiers.

The game ends when there is only one person left alive.

Gear Grinders is the first game from Roll One Games Limited.

Game time is 30 minutes to 2 hours depending on the number of players and the aggressiveness of the game play.

“It is both the duty and the tradition of the Royal Navy to engage the enemy wherever there is water to float a ship”

A “fast play” game covering primarily the naval engagements on Lake Tanganyika during the First World War, and also any number of real and hypothetical small craft actions during the period 1910-1920. Written with 1/600 scale models in mind, their inspiration being the models designed by North Head Miniatures of New Zealand.

As well as the tactical rules, a set of mini campaign rules is included. Actions fought using the tactical rules tend to be short and sharp, and so the campaign is easily playable in a few evenings, or as a club project for a day.

A good theme park tycoon knows that his or her best chances of becoming not only wealthy, but a legend in the industry is to build a park that is not only profitable, but one that keeps its Parkies happy! In Parkies, you'll strive to do exactly that. You'll compete with 2 to 6 players to build the best theme park possible, while attempting to attract the Parkies. Parkies are the absolute power in the game, so good Parkie management is as important as your ability to construct an interesting park.

In a nutshell, a series of attractions will become available on each turn. You and the other players will bid on those attractions. The winners take those attractions and add them to their park, increasing the park's allure, profitability, and/or satisfaction. Then you use those attractions to attempt to lure an interesting mix of Parkies to your park. The park with the happiest Parkies at the end of the game wins!

User summary

Players are all girls fighting a dragon with their swords. On a player's turn, he will roll a die to attack the dragon, and if successful, may add new cards to his sword, making it longer. The player may also play cards for special effects.

The dragon will attack the girls each round. The goal is to remain standing when the Final Round starts (round 7, if not triggered earlier), and defeat the dragon. The player with most points at the end wins.

link.value: Long Long Long Sword Girl!: Girls and Dragon!!

item.description:
User summary

A party-esque card game, where one plays the human, and the rest play the monkeys who have escaped from zoo. The cards depict various places where the monkeys may have gone. The monkey players will play these each turn, and at the end of each turn, flip them face up. The human player may to a certain extent look at the monkey players' hand cards, and try to block certain cards from being flipped face up, or simply catch the monkey who is in a specific place.

If the monkeys manage to get a certain amount of cards flipped face up, they win. If not, the human wins.

This game was created by everyone at One Draw, which is why there is no specified designer.

User summary

An idol-themed card game. Players are all a member of an idol group, but while being in the same group, wants to be voted to top idol. Each player has a set of cards with votes and scandals on and will play these onto the other members of the group. Each player also has one member they openly support.

Of the set cards each player has, one is Backstage Deal, which alows the player to play cards on a specific sheet, where each played cards will have various effects.

The player with the most votes at the end of the game wins.

User summary

A cooperative game where the players are all members of an idol group, aiming to create a million hit.

At the beginning of the game, a number of Appeal cards are lined up by each member of the idol group. These cards can, during the game, be looked at by players and can also switch places to and fro.

These appeal cards must match the requirements on the popularity sheet and come in a specific order, in order to generate a specific amount of sales. The goal of the game is to get as high sales as possible

A bundle containing the two games Idol Conclave and Million Hit Chart

item.description:
ãƒ€ã‚¤ã‚¹ æœ¨ (Daisuki) is a game in which the players take on the role of lumberjacks, chopping down trees in the mountain forest in order to collect wood and build houses. Along the way, they will run into fires and termites, but the lumberjack who can hold onto the most wood and build the best buildings will win!

The game starts with a mountain made of wood disks. Players take turns drawing a disk at random and revealing what they have "harvested" from the forest. As players start controling more wood, they can use those wood chips to buy better equipment, put out fires, build houses, etc. It's a chance and dice game of press-your-luck with a little bit of attack-your-opponents as well!

link.value: game no dendo (ゲームの殿堂)

item.description:
Simple roll-and-move game.

It's a bedtime game for children - players roll the die and move their pawns, following the directions when they land on certain spaces - e.g. move forward, skip a turn...

Notes:
Predecessor of Sandmann, lieber Sandmann. Different editions were published during mid 1960s

name.value: 13 Días: La crisis de los misiles en Cuba
13 Giorni: La Crisi dei Missili di Cuba 1962
13 Jours: La Crise des missiles de Cuba 1962

item.description:
Experience the dense Cold War suspense and scratch that Twilight Struggle itch in only 45 minutes.

13 Days: The Cuban Missile Crisis is a nail-biting, theme saturated two-player strategy game about the Cuban Missile Crisis. Your fate is determined by how well you deal with the inherent dilemmas of the game, and the conflict.

1) Will you push to gain prestige at the risk of escalating the crisis to global nuclear war?
2) How do you best manage your hand of cards to further your own plans while depriving your opponent of options?

Work out these dilemmas in order to emerge as victor of the Cuban Missile Crisis after thirteen suspenseful days.

13 Days: The Cuban Missile Crisis is a meaty filler utilizing the card-driven game mechanisms. Rich with history, yet accessible to gamers with no prior knowledge of the crisis. It is targeted specifically at catering to two groups of gamers: the enthusiasts that just don't have the time they used to and the curious newcomers that are scared off by the heavy commitment and long play times of the classics in the genre.

Official FAQ/ERRATA
Designer Diary

name.value: SAVAGE WAR OF PEACE: A Solitaire Game of the Algerian War (1954-1962).

item.description:
SAVAGE WAR OF PEACE is a solitaire game of Combat during the French-Algerian War (1954-1962). The player assumes the role of a commander of combined French forces in Algeria. As commander, you are responsible for securing your Area of Operations (AOR) by successfully conducting various military operations in order to locate and destroy the enemy. Although there are many units available to you, they may often times be limited to you by political, logistical or geographical obstacles.

GAME OBJECTIVE
The objective of SAVAGE WAR OF PEACE is to successfully complete a number of missions and destroy enemy forces in order to gain Victory Points (VP) for the French Forces. The player can choose to play a short game (4 Missions), an average game (6 Missions), a long game (8 Missions) or a full Tour (12 Missions). Once all Missions have been resolved (successfully or not) the Player totals his VP and compares this with the Victory Determination Table to determine the level of success.

name.value: Fireforce: Rhodesia – A Solitaire Game of the Rhodesian War (1964-1979)

item.description:
FIREFORCE: RHODESIA is a solitaire game of the Rhodesian War. The player assumes the role of a Commander of a combined Force of Rhodesian Security Forces, including the Rhodesian Light Infantry (RLI), Rhodesian SAS and the Elite, Selous Scouts. As commander, you are responsible for securing your Area of Operations (AOR) by successfully conducting various military operations in order to locate and destroy the enemy ZANLA and ZIRPA forces. Although there are many units available to you, they may often times be limited to you by political, logistical or geographical obstacles.

GAME OBJECTIVE 
The objective of FIREFORCE: RHODESIA is to successfully complete a number of missions and destroy enemy forces in order to gain Victory Points (VP) for the Security Forces. The player can choose to play a short game (4 Missions), an average game (6 Missions), a long game (8 Missions) or a full Tour (12 Missions). Once all Missions have been resolved (successfully or not) the Player totals his VP and compares this with the Victory Determination Table to determine the level of success.

name.value: TRADITION OF GLORY: A Game of Naval Adventure during the Age of Nelson.

item.description:
INTRODUCTION
The year is 1795 and France is gathering their Forces for their Armies and Navy in a grand attempt to conquer Europe. It is also a time of revolutions, imperialism, piracy and political intrigue. In this game, you start out as a young Officer serving in the British Royal Navy. As you complete missions, you will gain experience, honor and hopefully promotions. In time, you may command a Ship of your own. This game is for fans of the Nautical Fiction Series of Horatio Hornblower, Richard Bolitho and Jack Aubrey.

OBJECTIVE
In TRADITION OF GLORY each player creates a Player Officer starting out in what will, hopefully be, a long and glorious career in the Royal Navy. During, play, Player Officers (POs) will be assigned to Ships and conducting a variety of Missions as they move along the Career Track Game Board. The Career Track consists of Ports, Sea Travel and Ship Duty Assignments. These Assignments will result in a variety of situations and encounters including Naval Battles, Port Assaults, Land Skirmishes, Shore Bombardment as well as a variety of other Missions in which the Player’s Officer must resolve. The outcome of these Encounters and Situations determine whether the Player’s Officer advances along the Career Track. While the Officers conduct Challenges, they might gain or lose Merit Points, which are used to improve their Attribute Ratings and Rank. The Player Officer with the Highest Rank after reaching the Ending Space on the Career Track, is the Winner. If this is tied, then the Officer with the most Merit Points remaining is the Winner. If this is tied then the Officers may conduct a Duel to determine the Winner.

name.value: Terminator Genisys: The Miniatures Game – The War Against The Machine

item.description:
NOTE: The "War against the Machines edition" has a full 128 page manual with future expansions planned and is intended for wargamers. The "Battle for the Future" edition is more intended for the general gaming public.

Terminator Genisys: The War Against the Machines features 31 stunning plastic miniatures designed to be ready for action in minutes. No glue is required, thanks to their push-fit design, and they come in two clear different plastic colour (metallic grey for the Terminators and army green for the Resistance) to make sure you recognise your forces easily amidst the fog of war.

As a bonus, The War Against the Machines includes a superbly sculpted metal Kyle Reese character to join the Resistance fighters, providing them with special command abilities and heroic traits, Kyle Reese is a perfect to lead the brave Resistance soldiers against the endoskeletons.

Terminator Genisys: The War Against the Machines includes a 128 pages rulebook that allows you to explore every game possibility; starting from the contents of the box but allowing you to expand with the upcoming range of heroes, commanders, troop types and vehicles expected during the year ahead. We will keep you well informed about all these new exciting releases.

While you can play on your regular gaming table, we have included a 2’x3′ double-sided gaming mat, cardboard measuring templates and a set of cardboard terrain to make it a game truly ready out of the box, so you’ll be up and running in no time at all.

Finally, the unique dice game system invites you to play without the need of modifiers or tables and the chaotic “Fate activation system” ensure you’re always involved in the action.

Contents:

Full-colour rulebook: 128 pages Exclusive metal Kyle Reese model (brings special abilities, command options and heroic feats) 10 Terminator Endoskeletons (Two different posses, advancing and… relentlessly advancing!) 5 Terminator Crawlers (You thought the ENDO was done?!) 16 Resistance Soldiers (with a selection of weapons from missile launchers to plasma rifles!) Quickstart rules: 16 pages 2 punchboards: Includes all the scenery, tokens and gaming aids needed to play! 1 full colour double-sided 2’x3′ gaming mat 1 full-colour double-sided rules reference sheet 13 colour-coded dice: 2 sets of D4, D6, D8, D10, D12, D20 1 custom made metal colour Fate die

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
This simple roll-and-move-game was published as an insert in a "Toffifee" Box and promotes the second "Die drei ???" movie as well as "Toffifee".
The first player to reach the diamonds and answers corectly a question from the question card wins the game. On certain spaces events occur, that hinder or benefit the player. If a player gets on a space with a picture, he has to perform an action as described on the action card.

This game was published on a "Toffifee" Box. The players roll a die. At the result of an even number, the player takes a random christmas Ornament, places it on the christmas tree and gets points awarded, as noted on the ornament. The gameeEnds when all ornaments are placed on the tree. The player with the most points wins the game.

Reclaim Neverland is a strategy game that takes place in Peter Pan's Neverland that is under siege by four pirate captains.

Reclaim Neverland is unlike other deckbuilding games because of the combination of PvP elements and a limitation to the size of each players built deck. Similar to its predecessor, Reclaim Oz, It is a unique tabletop experience that has the play differently than any other games in the same genre. We have added items to the game as well, these will work as multipliers and bonuses for specific characters!

The game takes place in Neverland, home to famous characters such as Peter Pan, Tinker Bell, and Tiger Lily, but at a time when a new band of pirates, including Captain James Hook, are mounting a siege on the inhabitants. All the great Heroes of Neverland have disappeared, and four Pirates from the Mainland have taken over. While J. M. Barrie may have written a much happier world, this is still the same place, with all the characters and places you know and love—but in a time of great terror. The game has several animals, beasts, and mythos from the original book Peter and Wendy including characters from Little White Bird—it is your task to get the World back to the way it once was, with the characters you collect along the way. If you are able to compile the best deck filling each of the categories (HERO, BRAVE, LOST), you win!

A roll-and-move, question-and-answer trivia game with 1200 general knowledge questions about the British Isles. There are six question categories:


 History & legends
 Famous people
 Art & entertainment
 General trivia
 Geography
 Sport

Back cover text (translated):

"Swop it" means "to trade", and that's exactly what this game is about -- trading clothes with each other! First, let the clothes-spinner determine who you will challenge, and which item of clothing you two will exchange with each other, then the countdown begins. Let the clothes fly! The person who first succeeds at removing their piece of clothing and putting on the exchanged piece gets to go forward on the gameboard.


The game is played to 23 points (with more points given out in a round if the winner finishes trading clothes before the timer runs out).
